channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin’s Forever War
item.description: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Putin’s Forever War

item.title: Swiss Women Sue Government Over Climate Change Protections
item.description: A group of Swiss women over 64 have filed a lawsuit against Switzerland with Europe’s top human rights court, saying the country has violated their rights by failing to curb emissions.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of KlimaSeniorinnen, or Senior Women for Climate Protection, with the French environmental activist and member of the European Parliament Marie Toussaint, third from right, in 2020 in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: ‘Barbie’ Is a Sleeper Hit in China
item.description: The movie has exceeded box office expectations, as China’s female moviegoers celebrate a film that addresses women’s rights head-on.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
item.media:description: Despite its limited availability in China, the movie “Barbie” has quickly become widely discussed on Chinese social media, setting off its own mini mania in some circles.

item.title: In Egypt, Public Classrooms Are Empty as Private Tutors Get Rich
item.description: In a country hobbled by economic crisis, families often turn to private education centers instead of schools to seek better futures for their children, sometimes even sacrificing food to pay for lessons.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Nariman El-Mofty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian students crammed into the Excellent-Oxford Tutoring Center in a suburb of Cairo for a five-hour private math lesson.

item.title: Pope Francis Declines to Condemn Russia at Fatima Shrine in Portugal
item.description: “It’s not enough just to listen — he has to do something,” said Dmytro Bohak, one of about 500 young Ukrainian pilgrims who attended the event and staged a demonstration.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Francis waving to pilgrims in Fátima, Portugal, on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine War Expands Beyond Old Battlefields
item.description: Russia has turned to regular attacks on the Black Sea, a vital economic hub, while Ukraine has grown bolder, with strikes hitting Moscow and Russian ships.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Kharkiv on Friday.

item.title: How a U.S. Tech Mogul Used Nonprofits to Sow Chinese Propaganda
item.description: The Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl, David A. Fahrenthold, Lynsey Chutel and Ishaan Jhaveri
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Neville Roy Singham, right, in 2016 with the activist Jodie Evans. In 2017, they married and he sold his tech firm.

item.title: Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds
item.description: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the Russian state news media showed President Vladimir V. Putin holding a child in Kronstadt, near St. Petersburg, last month.

item.title: Imran Khan Sentenced to Prison in Pakistan
item.description: The former prime minister of Pakistan was taken into custody, sentenced to three years after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan signing bond documents at an office of the high court last month in Lahore.

item.title: Niger is Latest African Country Where France’s Fortunes are Fading
item.description: A recent military takeover in Niger has thrown into uncertainty the future of France’s presence in West and Central Africa, raising doubts about the future of U.S. military involvement there, too.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Protesters holding the flag of Niger on Thursday, the nation’s independence day, in the capital, Niamey.

item.title: An Israeli City Where Compromise and Division Swim Side by Side
item.description: At a time when Israeli Jews can seem irreconcilably divided, an unusual swimming center in the city of Rehovot illustrates the compromises that many Israelis make daily.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children playing in the religious pool during its males-only hours in Rehovot, Israel, last month.

item.title: Ukraine Invites Talks in Saudi Arabia as an Effort to Weaken Russia
item.description: Some 40 countries that have largely remained on the sidelines of the war were invited to talks on Saturday in Saudi Arabia, as Ukraine redoubles international efforts to isolate Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Vivian Nereim and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Saudi state media showed President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in May in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Thousands of Scouts Leaving South Korea Jamboree Early
item.description: The British, Singaporean and U.S. scouting organizations cited health concerns for their departure from a much-anticipated youth event in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Scouts resting in the shade at the World Scout Jamboree in Buan, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Battle at Sea Intensifies as Ukraine Drone Hits 2nd Russian Ship in 2 Days
item.description: In addition to the strike on an oil tanker, Ukraine issued a warning that commercial ships using any of six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered military targets.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Planet Labs showed a damaged Russian warship near the port of Novorossiysk, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: Victim of Mass Attack in South Korea Dies
item.description: The victim was one of 14 people hurt in a car-and-stabbing rampage on Thursday in a city near Seoul. She had been hit by the car.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A police officer cordoning off the scene of the attack in Seongnam, South Korea, on Thursday.

item.title: Henri Konan Bédié, Ivory Coast President Deposed in a Coup, Dies at 89
item.description: As a longtime power broker he helped make his West African country an economic dynamo, but in office he fomented ethnic divisions and cracked down on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Henri Konan Bédié in 2020. He played a dominant role in Ivorian politics over six decades. His quiet confidence and back-room influence earned him the nickname “the Sphinx of Daoukro,” after his hometown.

item.title: Palestinian Kills Israeli in Tel Aviv, a Day After West Bank Violence
item.description: A gunman from Jenin, West Bank, shot and killed an Israeli security guard on Saturday. It came the evening after a Palestinian was killed in a fight with Israeli settlers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A street in Tel Aviv where an Israeli security guard was shot on Saturday by a Palestinian gunman. The victim was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital.

item.title: ‘Rooftopping’ Is Popular on Instagram, but the Risks Are High
item.description: “Rooftoppers” get a thrill from taking photos atop skyscrapers and sharing them on social media. Detractors call them reckless.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Tiffany May

item.title: Canada Moves Forward With New Tech Tax
item.description: An international overhaul to tax tech companies is at a standstill, so Canada is forging ahead with another plan.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A Meta sign outside of the company’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., in March.

item.title: Arrests for Online Threats of Copycat Attacks in South Korea
item.description: Posts online in the wake of recent stabbing assaults specified sites for copycat attacks. They prompted swift police action in a nation rattled by the random violence.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of a stabbing in Seoul on July 21 that left one person dead and three others injured. There was a second stabbing attack near the city this month.

item.title: Ukraine Hits a Distant Russian Ship, Showing Reach of Naval Drones
item.description: The attack damaged the warship hundreds of miles from Ukrainian-held territory, as Kyiv increasingly tries to bring the war home to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: Greece Will Limit Acropolis Visits as Europe Fights Tourist Crush
item.description: Greece is trying to curb overcrowding and prevent damage at its most popular archaeological site. Other European destinations are also cracking down.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Home to the Parthenon, the Acropolis has attracted up to 23,000 visitors each day. The new limits will cap visitors at 20,000 a day.

item.title: ‘Too Patriarchal’ Father in India Now Champions Women’s Rights
item.description: A delivery room epiphany transformed a village headman into an unlikely and highly successful campaigner against prenatal sex testing, which often led to aborting female fetuses.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunil Jaglan, center, discussing health issues with women in a farming village in Haryana State in India, where he has led a campaign against prenatal sex testing.

item.title: Young Catholics Come Together, if Not Their Views
item.description: As young Catholics gathered from around the world in Portugal, their desires for the future of the church were as varied as the countries they came from.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jose Sena Goulao
item.media:description: Crowds greeting Pope Francis in Lisbon on Wednesday.

item.title: Supreme Court in India Gives Rahul Gandhi a Path Back to Parliament
item.description: India’s main opposition leader was kicked out of the legislature after a defamation case that his allies called politically motivated. He can also now run in next year’s elections.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, center, was barred from Parliament after a lower court in the prime minister’s home state gave him a two-year prison sentence.

item.title: What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by Ukraine
item.description: The seaport is one of Russia’s largest by volume and among the biggest in Europe, crucial to the export of Russian grain, oil, and other products to countries around the world.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Oil tankers moored in Novorossiysk, Russia, last October.

item.title: Anger in China Over Flooding of Towns, in Part, to Save Beijing
item.description: A provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A rescue worker pulling a boat carrying residents in a flooded area near Zhuozhou, China, on Thursday.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Released From House Arrest in Romania
item.description: The online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, a court in Bucharest ruled.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Matei Barbulescu
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, center, and his brother Tristan, right, inside the Bucharest Court of Appeals building this week.

item.title: Niger’s Detained President, Mohamed Bazoum, Pleads for U.S. Help
item.description: The military junta that ousted the president in the West African nation of Niger last week also dismissed Niger’s ambassadors to key partners: the United States, France and Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: President Mohamed Bazoum of Niger in Washington last year. Unlike other ousted leaders in the region, he has refused to formally resign, and he and his family are being held in his private residence.

item.title: TSMC Chairman Mark Liu Says Company Will Keep Its Roots in Taiwan
item.description: In an interview, the chip maker’s chairman, Mark Liu, explained why TSMC’s top tech would stay in Taiwan, despite growing threats from China and worries from the United States.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Liu, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, said it would be difficult to replicate what the company has built in Taiwan.

item.title: New Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious Predators
item.description: A close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish.
item.dc:creator: Darren Incorvaia

item.title: Japan’s High School Baseball Tournament is the Sound of Summer
item.description: Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones.
item.dc:creator: Brad Lefton
item.media:description: As teams march into Koshien Stadium for the National High School Baseball Championship, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” serves as the soundtrack.

item.title: The Chip Titan Whose Life’s Work Is at the Center of a Tech Cold War
item.description: At 92, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, can no longer stay in the shadows.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: After Ukraine’s Kakhovka Dam Disaster, a Hunt for Ancient Treasures
item.description: After the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Jailed Russian Opposition Leader, Receives 19-Year Sentence
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, who is already in prison, was sentenced for supporting “extremism,” amid intensified suppression of dissent in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, second from the left, appearing at a Moscow City Court hearing with his lawyers via video link on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s day in court.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Australians’ ‘Golden Ticket’ to the U.S.
item.description: Proposed changes to the E-3 visa have worried some expatriates.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons at Ruby’s Cafe, an Australian coffee shop in Manhattan.

item.title: Meta Removes News From Platform in Canada
item.description: A Canadian law that will require tech companies to compensate domestic publishers has led Meta to start blocking news articles on its social networks.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Meta has followed through with a threat to restrict access to news content in protest of a new Canadian law.

item.title: Russia’s Pro-War Bloggers Are Suddenly Sniping Among Themselves
item.description: A new tone has set in among the uninhibited military bloggers, whose support for the invasion has given them unusual powers to speak out.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian solder in a kindergarten near the front line in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: Winter Heat Wave Grips Chile, Argentina and Other South American Countries
item.description: An unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Natalie Alcoba
item.media:description: Buenos Aires broke an 81-year-old daily temperature record on Tuesday.

item.title: Seiichi Morimura, 90, Who Exposed Japanese Wartime Atrocities, Dies
item.description: In a widely read book, he detailed gruesome biological experiments on people at a secret Imperial Army site in occupied China before and during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Seiichi Morimura at his desk in Tokyo in 2015. A mystery novelist, he began investigating Japanese army medical experiments after a former participant in the program contacted him.

item.title: 2 U.S. Navy Sailors Charged With Spying for China
item.description: Prosecutors said the two sailors in California gave Chinese intelligence officers U.S. military secrets and sensitive information.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Jill Cowan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: One of the two Navy sailors accused of spying was assigned to a ship based at Naval Base San Diego. The charges appear to reflect the Chinese government’s deep interest in the U.S. Navy’s Pacific Fleet.

item.title: Poland and Lithuania Warn Against ‘Provocations’ From Wagner in Belarus
item.description: The notice came a few days after two helicopters bearing Belarusian flags violated Polish airspace.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: President Gitanas Nauseda of Lithuania, left, and Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland during a news conference on Thursday in northeastern Poland, near both countries’ borders with Belarus.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Home Scaled by Greenpeace Protesters in Britain
item.description: The incursion by opponents of oil drilling raised concerns about the security of the British leader and his family.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A photograph provided by Greenpeace UK shows activists climbing up to the roof of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s home in North Yorkshire.

item.title: Colombia Rebel Group ELN and Government Begin Cease-Fire
item.description: A six-month truce began on Thursday between the government and the largest remaining insurgency, the far-left group known as the National Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti indicating the presence of E.L.N. guerrillas in Anorí, a town in the Antioquia region of Colombia.

item.title: 14 Injured in Car Rampage and Stabbing Near Seoul
item.description: Thursday’s early-evening attack comes less than a month after another mass stabbing episode, also in the Seoul region, that left one victim dead and three injured.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Rescue workers Thursday on the scene in a Seoul suburb where more than a dozen people were hurt in a stabbing and car rampage.

item.title: Hundreds Fall Ill From Heat at World Scout Jamboree in South Korea
item.description: As the country endures its hottest summer in years, at least 125 people were hospitalized and many others were treated for symptoms during baking conditions at the World Scout Jamboree.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Participants for the 25th World Scout Jamboree arriving at a camping site in Buan County, South Korea, on Tuesday.

item.title: Australia Will Return Looted Sculptures to Cambodia
item.description: A centuries-old Buddhist sculpture was taken from a rural area in Cambodia nearly 30 years ago. It was later sold with two other statues to the National Gallery of Australia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: via The National Gallery of Australia
item.media:description: Bronze sculptures of Bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara Padmapani and attendants, which will be returned from Australia to Cambodia.

item.title: The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in China
item.description: Many writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.
item.dc:creator: Han Zhang
item.media:credit: Tommy Kha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hao Qun and an unnamed writer. Hao, who once enjoyed a successful writing career in China, fled to Australia after facing persecution.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The future of U.S. politics after Donald Trump’s indictment.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainians Shun a Church Seen as a Kremlin Tool
item.description: The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parishioners leaving church after a service in Blystavytsya, Ukraine. The village has switched its allegiance from the Russian Orthodox Church to the Ukrainian national church.

item.title: VanMoof’s Bankruptcy Worries Owners of Electric Bikes
item.description: VanMoof’s sleek electric bikes attracted fans, but the Dutch company’s demise has left owners unable to get repairs and worried that app-enabled functions may stop working.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cyclist on a VanMoof bike in Amsterdam. The maker of electric bicycles declared bankruptcy last month.

item.title: Niger Coup: Here’s What to Know
item.description: Amid an unpredictable military coup, neighboring countries have threatened to go to war — some to scuttle the coup, and others to ensure its success.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Protesters cheering Nigerien troops in front of the French Embassy in Niamey during a demonstration that followed a rally in support of the junta on Sunday.

item.title: South Korean Ferry Disaster Figure Yoo Hyuk-kee Is Extradited
item.description: Yoo Hyuk-kee’s family company ran the Sewol ferry, whose sinking off the South Korean coast left hundreds dead. Prosecutors have charged Mr. Yoo, a U.S. resident, with embezzlement.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Yoo Hyuk-kee, center, at Incheon International Airport in South Korea on Friday.

item.title: ‘Kill the Boer’ Song Fuels Backlash in South Africa and U.S.
item.description: Right-wing commenters claim that an old anti-apartheid chant is a call to anti-white violence, but historians and the left-wing politician who embraces it say it should not be taken literally.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Julius Malema gesturing from the stage on Saturday during the 10th anniversary celebrations of his political party in Johannesburg.

item.title: A Leader of Niger’s Coup Visits Mali, Raising Fears of a Wagner Alliance
item.description: Several military officials who took power from the president in Niger last week met with the leaders of Mali, where the Kremlin-backed Wagner mercenary group has deployed about 1,500 troops.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Office of the President of Mali
item.media:description: In this photograph released by the Malian presidency, Assimi Goïta, center, Mali’s interim president, met on Wednesday in Bamako, the capital, with Gen. Salifou Modi, left, one of the military leaders who ousted the president of Niger last week.

item.title: Iranians Blame Power Grid and Gas Shortage for Shutdown Amid Heat
item.description: The government in Tehran cited “unprecedented” heat when it ordered a two-day shutdown to protect health and conserve energy, but many residents were not buying it.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: A dried-out riverbed in Isfahan, Iran.

item.title: Are the Trump Indictments a Turning Point? History Says Not Likely.
item.description: The latest indictment of former President Donald J. Trump takes the United States to an uncharted place in its history. But other countries’ histories suggest that the prosecution of leaders accused of wrongdoing cannot fix underlying problems.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election Case)
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump at a rally for his 2024 presidential campaign in Erie, Pa., on Saturday.

item.title: Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’
item.description: Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly all Americans have built up multiple layers of immunity following repeated infections, immunizations or both, so the virus is unlikely to cause the harm this winter that was seen in previous seasons.
